headline.main: THE FLORANCE NIGHTINGALE OF THE NURSERY.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is an extract from a letter written by the Rev. C.Z. Weizer, to the German Reformed Messenger, at Chambersburg, Penn.:

docs.snippet: By the arrival of the bark Harriet Brewster, Capt. HAWKINS, we have received advices from Havana to May 6. The weather was very hot. Many arrangers waiting to leave, but find it difficult, owing to the absence of the regular steamers. The Harriet...
docs.lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the bark Harriet Brewster, Capt. HAWKINS, we have received advices from Havana to May 6. The weather was very hot. Many arrangers waiting to leave, but find it difficult, owing to the absence of the regular steamers. The Harriet Brewster has no passengers, Mrs. M.A.F. CURTIS, of Boston, and HENRY BARTLETT, of Newburyport.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: CIVIL WAR (THE WAR BETWEEN THE STATES)

docs.snippet: No demonstration has yet been made on the part of the Government, indicative of the course which it intends to pursue. It is still engaged in strengthening its hands for the contest, and it is thought in some quarters that it will continue to do so,...
docs.lead_paragraph: No demonstration has yet been made on the part of the Government, indicative of the course which it intends to pursue. It is still engaged in strengthening its hands for the contest, and it is thought in some quarters that it will continue to do so, until the certainty of success cannot be questioned. It is believed that delay will be advantageous to the Government, while it will prove the contrary to its enemies.
